title: Hogging up all the resources on hackerone.com

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
***Please note.*** *I believe that some of the issues described below can also be used on their own and/or combined in other configurations to achieve different results, e.g. "paying" a bounty of zero or team avoiding to resolve and unpleasant issue. I am however describing the (very likely) doomsday scenario.*

The following report IDs were used in testing: 125555, 125556. After you're done with this bug, please remove those. **DO NOT OPEN BEFORE READING THE FULL REPORT**

To reproduce the problem immediately, just skip to **Bug5**.

**Bug1. It is possible to award bounties of size zero.** *(not required for doomsday)*
hackerone has implemented a filter on minimal bounty amount. It is impossible to award negative bounty, zero bounty or "0.00" bounty. This is checked by JavaScript and furthermore on the server side. However, it is possible to award "0.001" bounty, effectively awarding zero amount. This allows a team to risk no money when executing next steps.

**Bug2. POST to `bulk` is susceptible to a replay attack .** *(not required for doomsday)*
This of course only makes the following attack easier, but POST to https://hackerone.com/reports/bulk can be replayed without changing a thing in the request. A dynamic use-once token is strongly advised.

**Bug3. Many `Activities::BountyAwarded` on a bug report hog up server resources because of unoptimized codebase.** 
*Note. Other types of activities may also be affected. This was not further clarified due to severe impact on hackerone infrastructure.*
It was measured that with each new activity added https://hackerone.com/reports/NNNNNN.json became slower and slower.
Please see the following table where cnt is the count of Activities::BountyAwarded in a bug report and spd is the time (in seconds) it took for the json to load.
```
cnt		spd
335		13
380		15
440		19
485		23
555		24
680		26
750		28
```
This already makes the specific bug report quite unusable.

**Bug4. Cloudflare is configured to disconnect the HTTP session if the response takes longer than 30 seconds.** *(not required for doomsday)*
This is generally a good thing, but considering the previous bug this means that at some amount of `Activities::BountyAwarded` we effectively make report inaccessible to anyone. I reached this point in my testing with approx 800 activities per report. Note that I did not try to find the specific limit due to the severe impact of this bug on hackerone infrastructure. Additionally the specific number is probably dependant on the server load anyway.
*Please see the attached screenshot "offline.png".*

Still I am quite sure that a report can only have less than a thousand activities of this type.
After Cloudflare has disconnected a HTTP session, it does not automatically reconnect, so this can be further used to make the user believe that he is logged out. Probably some other nefarious purposes.
*Please see the attached screenshot "logged-out.png", I am infact logged-in at that moment.*

**Bug5. Just 10 parallel requests to the json file is enough to paralyse hackerone.com for everyone.**
```
for((x=0;x<10;x++)); do (curl https://hackerone.com/reports/NNNNNN.json & ); done
```
This was tested on the report ID ending with 6. I ran the attack only twice. Second time to confirm that the unavailability was not a coincidence.
*Please see the attached file "DoS-impact-measurments.txt" for attack impact measurement.*

I am able to effectively permanently take down hackerone.com by sending just **14 thousand requests per day**. You state that you treat confidentiality bugs as "severe". This is an availability (+small part integrity) bug, but the impact is massive. I therefore urge that you consider this bug of the highest severity.


**Attack plan**
1. Get a vulnerability report
2. Fix it, agree on disclosure. It is now publicly available and visible on the front page.
3. Submit a 1000 rewards of 0.001 to the report.
4. Anyone who requests the json file (by opening the report on the front page for example) will get disconnected by Cloudflare.
5. If this is not enough to create a DDoS on the actual infrastructure hidden behind Cloudflare, you can just launch 10 parallel requests to the json file yourself every minute for a simple and elegant DoS.
6. ~~Profit.~~ Watch the world burn.

**Suggested fixes**
Bug1: round the value first, validate against >0 later.
Bug2: apply non-reusable tokens to your POST forms.
Bug3: hell if I know! you're not open source, right? take a look at your damn code. ;)
Bug4: might want to adjust the thresholds or reimplement your client-side (JavaScript) algorithms for detecting if a user is logged in or not.
Bug5: pre-generating actual json files for different audiences would surely reduce the load and eliminate this vector.

activities.message:
I am adding some clarifying information regarding the bugs.
**Bug1:** Seems that 0.001 is (in some cases) stored as NaN rather than 0.00.

**Bug3** might be caused by executing some action[s] (a db request?) for every activity. This should be optimised.

**Bug4:** In addition to tweaking Cloudflare settings, align your server settings with the timeout values! Currently it seems that while Cloudflare disconnects the connection, the server continues to be bogged down by the request. Server should sense the Cloudflare disconnect and terminate request and all its subprocesses on the server side.

Hey @kirils,

Due to the in-depth nature of your report, I've asked one of our engineers who has more experience with our infrastructure to help out here, we'll get back to you asap!

Kind regards,
Dirk

Hi @kirils,

Thanks for your report! Just wanted to restate that we're still looking into this. We hope to come back with a definitive answer by the end of this week. Thanks for your patience!
Thank you. Keeping me in the loop is much appreciated.

Hi @kirils,

If I understand you correctly, the gist of your report is that any report with a lot of activities (say, in the thousands) will be __very__ slow. So slow, in fact, that it's possible to DoS us by repeatedly requesting the json of the report in parallel.

We've looked into this and verified that this is indeed a way to DoS us. While admittedly not a high priority right now, this is something that we'll look into.

Yes. I'd also like to add that:
1) One thousand (or even a bit less) activities is more than enough.
2) I cannot overstate how easy It is. My calculations show that attack stream of **150 bps** is enough to fully take down the website. For a public report this can be done without an account from a changing IP address, so there's no easy way to mitigate this.
3) I suppose it isn't a high priority only because it's not being exploited right now. Taking down hackerone web is as critical as it gets, IMHO.

I don't this this will be fixed with a simple one-liner, so I wish you all the best in fixing this.

Hi @kirils,

Wanted to update you on this report. We're still working on a fix and aiming to release a fix later this week.
Great to hear that it's being worked on. Good luck!

Hi @kirils,

Wanted to give you a quick update that we're still investigating the issue. Will keep you posted!

Kind regards,
Maarten

Back from fixing to investigating? :)
I guess it's a complex issue.

Thanks for keeping me up to date!
Hey @kirils - Yup we're taking our time in fixing this. Will update you as soon as possible. Thanks for the patience!

Hi @kirils,

Thanks for your patience!

We've decided to add a relatively simple fix here. We've set a hard limit on the number of activities any given report will render. We expect that this is a sufficient enough solution for the time being.

Please confirm that this mitigates the problem.

I am still getting "Report failed to load" when trying to access #125555 via the web interface.

Also, the PoC I posted still takes down the server, if change 10 requests to 40 parallel requests.
```
for((x=0;x<40;x++)); do (curl https://hackerone.com/reports/NNNNNN.json & ); done
```


"The connection to the origin web server was made, but the origin web server timed out before responding. The likely cause is an overloaded background task, database or application, stressing the resources on your web server."

Hey @kirils,

We have somebody working on pagination right now, please hang tight, this is a tough one to fix!

Kind regards,
Dirk

I did not promise it would be easy. This is a severe bug... That's why I'm not pressuring you for time.

Please note there are actually multiple bugs at play here, so you might want to remember to get onto some of the others listed in this report when you're done with the root cause.

Yeah, it's a common issue with pretty much any heavy query on our system, and although the security impact is pretty low, it would be nasty if we were hit by something like this during a weekend. We'd probably need some heavy involvement of the H1 crew to keep us up, which is never fun.
Security impact is only low if you exclusively define security as â‰¡confidentiality, instead of using the full CIA triad. :)

Valid point. C and I aren't (or at least shouldn't) be influenced by this issue, and we do have a number of measures in place that would allow us to quickly recover from an attack like this, which does remedy the A impact a bit. Doesn't mean that it won't DoS our infrastructure team though ;)

Hello @kirils,

Wanted to let you know we're still actively working on this issue and that we haven't forgotten about you. Hang in there, will update when we have more information.

Kind regards,
Maarten
How actively are you "working on this"? Yes, I agree that this is a hard issue, however I think you've had quite a lot of time.
We're still working on this (it's requiring some refactoring that's taking longer than expected), but we want to reward you for your time in submitting this to us. We do apologize for the delay.

Thank you for assigning the reward.

I am however worried about this bug being open for such prolonged period of time. Can we agree on public disclosure date to get the things moving along?
How about 01DEC2016?
CVSS = 7.7

Dear HackerOne!
It's been 23 days since I proposed a disclosure date and I am still to get an initial response from you on that. Please understand that I need to plan my disclosure well ahead of time.

Needless to say this is not the kind of process I would expect from a trendsetter of responsible disclosure field. :(

Hi @kirils,

Sorry about not giving you a definitive timeline and for not having fixed this already. We're fixing this issue platform wide which is taking significant time. 

The fix is changing the backend in such a way that every request can give guarantees on max execution / processing time, aborting if it would take too long. This makes the problem big and complicated as it touches the entire surface of HackerOne. Though, the work already done is looking promising.

We're aware that we're currently exposed to this, which sucks when exploited, but we have an infra team around the clock to mitigate any problems until we've finished the automated solution.

Apologies it's taking this long and we'd appreciate it if you would not disclose this until we've finished our solution. Obviously we'd be happy to disclose after everything has been released.

I'll keep you updated!

Kind regards,
Maarten
I invite you to work with me to try and set a definitive fix date so I can plan my disclosure. I would definitely want to disclose this year.

Hey @kirils,

We're finalizing some small design issues on a fix for this, please bear with us just a little bit longer while we make this pretty too :)

Hey @kirils,

We just released a pagination implementation for report activities, which should make it a lot harder to pull down h1 with a few requests. For an example, take a look at #15518, which used to break.

Could you confirm our fix? Thanks for being so patient with us!

Cheers, Dirk

Phew! Finally. Took some time, but  seems fixed, even when accessing the json file directly. Thank you!
